Fogo SDK Documentation

This page is a work in progress – signup at fogo.io for updates.

Welcome to the Fogo SDK documentation. This page will walk you through everything you need to know to get started developing Apps for Fogo.

Getting Started

First, you need to download and install the following software:

  • Eclipse CDT
  • Fogo SDK (includes compiler and libraries – coming soon)
  • Fogo Link (desktop application for quickly installing and debugging programs)
  • Flashlight App Example Project (coming soon)

You start by importing the Flashlight app into Eclipse. Once imported, you can click on the build icon in Eclipse to build the application. Once built, you can put your Fogo in Debug mode by selecting Settings->Debug from the Fogo System settings App. Finally, you can use Fogo Link to install and re-install your new app.

Anatomy of an App

Fogo Apps are designed based on the Element class. An Element defines how the class will be drawn on the LCD in a scalable fashion as well as how to respond to events. Elements can use other elements to aid drawing on the screen. For example, the TextBox Element utilizes both Label and Text Elements.

There are two virtual methods that must be implemented for proper use:

  • Element::event_handler
  • Element::draw_to_scale

Element::event_handler handles events. Here is an example implementation:

Element * MyElement::event_handler(int event){
switch(event){
case CENTER_PRESS:
//do something awesome when the center button is pressed
break;
}
return Element::event_handler(event); //default handler for the reset of events
}

The Element::draw_to_scale method draws the Element as it is scaled to the bitmap. Here is an example:

void MyElement::draw_to_scale (MBitmap *b, mg_int_t x, mg_int_t y, const MDim &d, const ElementPadding &padding){
Icon icon;
mg_int_t w;
char buffer[32];
Label label;
switch(status){
case STATUS_RECORDING:
label.set_text("RECORD");
break;
case STATUS_PLAYING:
label.set_text("PLAY");
break;
case STATUS_IDLE:
label.set_text("");
break;
default:
//error
sprintf(buffer, "Err:%d", status);
label.set_text(buffer);
break;
}
label.set_dim(d.w(), d.h()/4);
label.draw_to_scale(b, x, y, label.dim(), label.padding());
w = d.w()*3/4 - padding.w();
icon.set_gfx(Icon::GFX_MIC, w, w, 3);
b->set_bitmap(icon, b->w()/2 - w/2, b->h()/2 - w/2);
}

The Element::draw method can be re-implemented in order to use other Elements as part of your new element. Here is an example:

MDim MyElement::draw (MBitmap *b, mg_int_t x, mg_int_t y, bool center){
//draw rect
_rect.set_dim(dim().w(), 2*dim().h()/100);
_title.set_dim(dim().w()*4/5, 15*dim().h()/100);
_status.set_dim(dim().w()/10, 15*dim().h()/100);
_text.set_dim(90*dim().w()/100, 83*dim().h()/100);
_title.draw(b, x, y);
_status.draw(b, x+80, y);
_rect.draw(b, x, y+15);
_text.draw(b, x+5, y+17);
return Element::draw(b,x,y,center);
}

A group of Elements can combined to create a more sophisticated UI. A Kit is used to execute animations between related elements. Pressing the center button will cause the Element to transition to the child (Element::child) while holding the center button transitions to the parent (Element::parent). Each Element can use Element::event_hanlder to customize how events are handled.
